Angioedema, vomiting, syncope, and rhinorrhea are common symptoms of a severe allergic reaction, such as anaphylaxis. Anaphylaxis is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate medical attention.

Angioedema, vomiting, syncope, and rhinorrhea can also be symptoms of a viral or bacterial infection. Viral infections that can cause these symptoms include the common cold, influenza, and viral gastroenteritis. Bacterial infections that can cause these symptoms include streptococcal pharyngitis, epiglottitis, and bacterial meningitis.
In some cases, angioedema, vomiting, syncope, and rhinorrhea can be caused by a non-infectious condition, such as a drug allergy or a food allergy.

Conjunctival injection is a symptom of inflammation of the conjunctiva, the clear membrane that covers the white part of the eye. Conjunctival injection can be caused by a variety of factors, including allergies, infections, and irritants.
The specific diagnosis will depend on the individuals medical history, physical examination, and laboratory tests.
If you are experiencing angioedema, vomiting, syncope, and rhinorrhea, it is important to seek medical attention immediately.

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): SLE can cause a wide variety of symptoms, including thrombocytopenia, proteinuria, maculopapular rash, and mononeuritis multiplex.

Sepsis: Sepsis is a serious condition that can cause widespread inflammation and organ damage. It can be caused by infection, injury, or other medical conditions. Sepsis can lead to a number of symptoms, including thrombocytopenia, proteinuria, maculopapular rash, and mononeuritis multiplex.
Vasculitis: Vasculitis is an inflammation of the blood vessels. It can cause a variety of symptoms, including thrombocytopenia, proteinuria, maculopapular rash, and mononeuritis multiplex.

Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP): HSP is a type of vasculitis that affects small blood vessels in the skin, joints, kidneys, and intestines. It can cause a number of symptoms, including thrombocytopenia, proteinuria, maculopapular rash, and abdominal pain.

Cryoglobulinemia: Cryoglobulinemia is a condition in which abnormal proteins called cryoglobulins circulate in the blood. Cryoglobulins can cause a variety of symptoms, including thrombocytopenia, proteinuria, maculopapular rash, and joint pain.

Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD): MCTD is a type of autoimmune disease that shares features of several other autoimmune diseases, including SLE, SSc, and polymyositis. MCTD can cause a variety of symptoms, including thrombocytopenia, proteinuria, maculopapular rash, and arthritis.
Rheumatoid arthritis (RA): RA is an autoimmune disease that affects the joints. It can also cause a number of other symptoms, including thrombocytopenia, proteinuria, maculopapular rash, and fatigue.

Sjögrens syndrome: Sjögrens syndrome is an autoimmune disease that affects the exocrine glands, such as the salivary and lacrimal glands. It can also cause a number of other symptoms, including thrombocytopenia, proteinuria, maculopapular rash, and dry eyes and mouth.

Scleroderma (SSc): SSc is an autoimmune disease that affects the skin, blood vessels, and internal organs. It can cause a variety of symptoms, including thrombocytopenia, proteinuria, maculopapular rash, and Raynauds phenomenon.

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN): PAN is a type of vasculitis that affects medium-sized arteries. It can cause a variety of symptoms, including thrombocytopenia, proteinuria, maculopapular rash, and abdominal pain.
